description.narrative:
Agri-ProFocus Uganda developed within its initial three years a unique network - the Agri-Hub - in Uganda that links a majority of the different stakeholders in the agri-business sector. It has become a vibrant network for information sharing, cooperation, doing business, learning and debate. Today, the Agri-Hub Uganda is excellently positioned to link, support and influence private sector development in agriculture and government policy in Uganda.
The results of the Agri-Hub Uganda are broken down infour areas broadly explained in the table below. 1. Network development and coordination: The Agri-Hub will serve as the port of call in Uganda for all stakeholders to create linkages and potential synergies with regard to farmer entrepreneurship and food security 2. Business and partnership brokering: With member cooperation the Agri-Hub establishes a pre-competitive environment to increase deal making in the agro- and food business, and facilitates joint resource mobilization. 3. Innovation communities: Groups of members cooperate thematically or sector wise to develop knowledge and solve practical issues. 4. Platform for debate and learning: The Agri-Hub provides a neutral platform for members to debate, learn from each other and exchange information

participating-org.narrative:
APF UGANDA COUNTERPART DESCRIPTION Agri-Profocus started in the Netherlands by civil society development organizations to establisha network/platform to discuss agricultural issues in the Netherlands. However, the initiators realized that it was not wise to concentrate on Netherlands but that scale up to developing countries where majority of the population are poor and engage in agriculture. APF has now spread to Kenya, Uganda, Rwanda and now Congo. • APF is a network of individuals and organizationinvolved in Agric-business sector. • APF is an on-line project and on its website, the partners can do marketing of their agricultural products, advertise, plan events among many things. • APF has committees and sub committees that help in steering theimplementation of the activitiesacross themes. • ONL is part of APF work and also supports CSOs who are actively involved in its implementation. APF Agri-Hub Uganda started in 2009 from the initiative of the Dutch members of the Agri-ProFocus network with the aim: to cooperate to promote farmerentrepreneurship in Uganda. Over the course of three years the initiative has grown into a unique network in Uganda that links the different stakeholders in the agri-business sector. It has become a vibrant network for information sharing, learning, debate, collaboration and innovation. Today the Agri-Hub Uganda is excellently positioned to link, support and influence private sector, development agencies and government. This is because the over almost 1600 professionals that have subscribed as members, are representing national and international development agencies, private sector companies including farmers, traders, input suppliers, processors and exporters amongst others, farmer organisations, knowledge institutions and government agencies.
The Agri-ProFocus Agri-Hub Uganda mission is to bring together the different actors in the Ugandan agricultural sector to promote a joint agenda on farmer entrepreneurship and food security, thus boosting the agricultural sector. APF Uganda focuses on three areas or pillars and 2 cross-cutting themes.
Focal areas 1. Supporting organised farmers with a focus on innovative business models, social capital and market linkages. 2. Fostering farmer entrepreneurship support systems with a focus on financial services, access to business development services, skills development and land tenure 3. Supporting sustainable food production for (domestic) markets and for the agro-food industry. Cross-cutting themes 1. Inclusiveness of service delivery (gender, ethnicity, youth). 2. Integrating economic growth with sustainability.
APF Uganda is hosted by SNV Uganda as a network consisting of professionals who are dedicated to supporting farmers who strive to become more entrepreneurial. The mission of the Agri-Hub is to create spaces and opportunities for business, multi–stakeholder action, and learning to enhance entrepreneurship among organised farmers in order for them to improve their livelihoods and food security. APFUganda believes that farmers are the key to local economic growth and sustainable Agri-food systems.
The Agri-Hub Uganda is recognized in the country as a network that brings together public, private, NGOs, farmer organizations, research institutions,all together for the development of the Agriculture sector. Members work under Innovation communities to join efforts in promoting farmer entrepreneurship and food security.
The Agri-Hub Uganda works through sharing and co-creating. Its’ results called ‘market triggers’ are effectively aimed to improve the support system for farmer entrepreneurship. Those improvements are called the ‘market uptake’: in other words how is the market of stakeholders responding, are the results of the network actually been put to good use. Furtherdown the line the improved support system should contribute to strong farmer entrepreneurs who are able to make better informed choices for their business.
The APF Uganda network is open to all actors seeking collaboration, exchange of information and strengthening the knowledge base; guiding principles being transparency and mutual accountability. The APF network of professionals hosts about 300 members.

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands

sector.narrative: The right to a sustainable livelihood

description.narrative: no. of partner organisations better able to communicate at the national and international levels the voice of people in rural areas living in poverty
